patient_information: 38-year-old European male expatriate, married, living in Malawi.
chief_complaint: Progressive constipation and difficulty passing urine for 3 weeks.
history_of_present_illness: For the past 3 weeks, the patient has experienced progressive constipation and difficulty passing urine, requiring increasing abdominal pressure and eventually passing only small amounts. This is associated with increasing lower abdominal discomfort, abnormal sensations in the groins and around the genitals, and some erectile dysfunction. He reports no weakness, dysaesthesia, or loss of sensation in his legs, but walking did not feel normal. There is no backache. Over the past 2 months, he has had unintentional weight loss of 8kg and fatigue without fever or night sweats. One week prior to presentation, he noticed reddish discoloration of his urine without painful micturition or fever. He visited a local clinic, where he was prescribed and completed four different types of medication. His previous medical history is unremarkable, and there is no history of trauma. He has sexual contact only with his wife.
exposure_and_epidemiology: Living in Malawi. He had swum regularly in Lake Malawi.
physical_exam: Healthy appearance. General examination showed no abnormalities except for a palpable bladder. Rectal examination revealed a low anal sphincter tone. Genital examination was normal. Neurological examination showed lively, symmetrical tendon reflexes in the legs without clonus or pathological plantar reflexes, and no other abnormalities.
labs_and_diagnostics: Prior to presentation at a local clinic: Schistosoma haematobium eggs identified in urine. At tertiary hospital: Abdominal ultrasound showed a large bladder residue after attempted micturition without further abnormalities. Full blood count showed normal absolute WBC (9 × 10^9/L) with relative eosinophilia of 21.8% (reference 1–6%) and absolute eosinophil count of 1.15 × 10^9/L (reference <0.45 × 10^9/L). ALT was slightly elevated. Creatinine and CRP were normal. HIV test and VDRL were negative. Microscopy of new stool and urine samples were normal. Serological tests for schistosomiasis were not available. MRI scan of the spinal cord showed an enhancing 1cm lesion at the anterior aspect of the conus with associated high T2 signal (oedema extending from the lower conus to T9). Nodular thickening of the urine bladder wall at the base and posterior aspect was also noted.
differential_diagnosis: Spinal cord schistosomiasis, spinal tuberculosis, spinal abscess, neurosyphilis, tumor or metastases impinging on the conus medullaris, bladder carcinoma.
management_and_clinical_course: Prior to presentation, he was treated with a full dose of praziquantel, ciprofloxacin, buscopan, and bisacodyl. At the tertiary hospital, the patient required urinary catheterization for 2 weeks. He made a full recovery after a second course of praziquantel and a course of high-dose prednisolone, tapered off over 2 months. He was well after more than 2 years of follow-up.
final_diagnosis: Schistosoma haematobium infection, complicated by spinal cord schistosomiasis with lesions in the conus medullaris causing a conus syndrome.
